question.title: When to use static methods
question.body:
I am wondering when to use static methods? Say if I have a class with a few getters and setters, a method or two, and I want those methods only to be invokable on an instance object of the class. Does this mean I should use a static method?

Example:

Obj x = new Obj();
x.someMethod();

...or:

Obj.someMethod(); // Is this the static way?

I'm rather confused!

answers.body:
Static methods are used when an instance of the class is not required. However, this does not mean that if you have created an instance, a static method should not be used. Here are several examples.

Here, the size could be different depending on the context. You could more than one list of students and the number could be different.

class  Students {
     private List<Students> List= new ArrayList<>();

     public int getNumberOfStudents() {
         return list.size();
     }
}

A static method is appropriate when doing some extraneous calculation as a helper method.

public class Statics {
      private double mean;
      private double stdDeviation;
      private double combinations;
   
   // helper method to compute factorial for some stat
   // calculations
   public static int factorial(int n) {
        if (n >= 0 && n <= 1) {
              return 1;
        }
        int nfactorial = 2;
        while (n-- > 3) {
            nfactorial *= ;
        }
        return nfactorial;
   }
   ...
   ...
   // other instance and or static methods as needed.
}
